title: Suspected Meteorite Hits Tesla Car’s Windscreen In South Australia | 10 News+
description: Dr Andrew Melville Smith was driving his Tesla along South Australia’s Port Augusta Highway when his windscreen shattered, spraying glass everywhere.   The heat radiating from his windscreen has led experts to suspect the rock that hit his car was a meteorite.   The South Australian Museum is now inspecting the damage and combing for clues of cosmic origin. title: Global Demand Surges For New Australian-Made Anti-Drone Laser Weapon | 10 News+
description: Australian defence company Electro Optics Systems has developed a groundbreaking new laser weapon called Apollo, which can shoot down drones on the battlefield with a beam of light.   It’s now in high demand around the globe, with the Netherlands being the first country to purchase the high-tech system.   The company says other NATO member states, as well as Middle Eastern and East Asian countries are interested in buying the anti-drone weapon too. title: Social Media Companies Face Senate Grilling Ahead Of Youth Ban | 10 News+
description: The owners of Facebook, Snapchat and TikTok have testified at a Senate inquiry ahead of the looming social media ban for users under the age of 16.   The tech giants have fought the ban from the start but insist they will comply once it takes effect in December.   Nationals Senator Ross Cadell has also made a bombshell claim, accusing TikTok of intimidating and bullying his office. title: King Charles Heckled As Prince Andrew Reportedly Agrees To Leave Royal Lodge | 10 News+
description: King Charles has been heckled over his brother Prince Andrew, with the protester shouting questions about Andrew’s links to Jeffrey Epstein as the monarch greeted fans outside a cathedral in north-west England.   It comes as reports indicate Andrew has agreed to leave the 30-bedroom Royal Lodge where he stays for a peppercorn rent. Royal Commentator Victoria Arbiter joined 10 News+ to break it all down. title: Jamaica Braces For Category 5 Hurricane Melissa To Make Landfall | 10 News
description: Hurricane Melissa is hours away from making a direct hit on Jamaica. Mandatory evacuations have been put in place in the capital, Kingston. Jamaica's Prime Minister is already pleading for help, warning no infrastructure in the region can withstand a Category Five hurricane. title: Woman Charged Over Cutting Gas Supply At Two Sydney Hospitals | 10 News
description: A woman has been charged, accused of shutting off the gas and water supply at two hospitals in Sydney's south, in what is being labelled deliberate sabotage. 10 News reporter Sarah Navin has the details. title: UFC Coming To Channel 10 & Paramount+ In 2026 | 10 News
description: The biggest fighting competition in the world has a new home: Paramount+ and Channel 10 will be the new home of UFC in Australia in 2026.  All UFC Fight Nights and the prelims for marquee numbered UFC events will be broadcast live on Paramount+ in Australia, as well as select live UFC events free-to-air on Channel 10.  The deal is an extension of the international UFC partnership signed with Paramount+ in the US earlier this year, and begins from January 1, 2026. title: Hurricane Melissa Weakens To Category 4 After Devastating Jamaica, Heads Towards Cuba | 10 News
description: Hurricane Melissa has weakened to a Category 4 system with sustained winds of 233kph as its eyewall moves off Jamaica’s northern coast, according to the latest National Hurricane Centre update.  The storm made landfall earlier Tuesday in Jamaica’s southwest with winds of up to 297kph, tearing apart homes, toppling trees and powerlines, and triggering widespread flooding and landslides.  Authorities say much of the island remains without power or communication, with entire communities cut off by blocked roads and debris.  Melissa is expected to make a second landfall in eastern Cuba late Tuesday or early Wednesday, still bringing life-threatening storm surge and damaging winds. title: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu Orders ‘Powerful’ Strikes On Gaza | 10 News
description: Israel has launched strikes on Gaza on Tuesday night after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu ordered the military to immediately carry out "powerful" attacks in the Palestinian territory.  It comes after Netanyahu accused Hamas of violating the two-week-old ceasefire agreement and staging the discovery of a deceased hostage.  At least eight people were killed in the strikes, including three in Gaza City's Sabra neighborhood and five in a car targeted in Khan Younis. title: Arnie The Murray Cod Tracked Swimming 900km Along Australia’s Biggest River System | 10 News
description: Aussies are known for our prowess in the water and one of us, named after an Olympic swimmer, has just broken a record.  Meet Arnie, a young Murray cod named after Champion swimmer Ariarne Titmus, that has travelled the largest known distance for the species.  10’s Late News explains. title: Alleged Drug Strikes Kill 14 In Pacific Ocean | 10 News
description: The US military has once again come under scrutiny after launching strikes on four suspected drug-smuggling boats in the eastern Pacific, killing 14 people and leaving one survivor.   Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said the vessels were linked to “designated terrorist organisations,” but legal experts have questioned the basis for using lethal force outside of war zones.   The Trump administration reportedly approved a classified opinion allowing traffickers to be treated as enemy combatants, a move critics say bypasses judicial oversight and international law.   Mexican authorities have taken charge of rescuing the survivor after being informed by Washington.   It’s the latest in a growing series of strikes raising ethical and legal concerns about the US’s expanding anti-narcotics campaign. title: Shark Feeding Frenzy Off Gold Coast's Snapper Rocks | 10 News
description: A spectacular but dangerous natural phenomenon has been caught on camera after a school of bait fish triggered a feeding frenzy at a popular Gold Coast surfing beach yesterday.  Videos posted to social media show a pack of sharks thrashing their fins and tails around in the shallows, attacking a bait ball right on the edge of the sand at Snapper Rocks.  It’s understood the swell has increased and all the bait has moved offshore, with no shark’s sighted since.  The beaches have re-opened, and lifeguards will continue to monitor the waters.
